context.text: A brief review of previous work on phase noise is given in [1].
In recent publications [1] and [2], we presented a theory and numerical methods for practical characterization of phase noise in oscillators with white-noise sources.
The characterization of phase noise in oscillators due to shot and thermal noise sources is covered by our theory of phase noise [1] due to white-noise sources.
Originally in [1], we developed the nonlinear perturbation analysis for oscillators based on an autonomous ordinary differential equation (ODE) formulation.

We carried out a rigorous analysis of this case in [1] and obtained the following results.

1)
The unperturbed oscillator's periodic response \$x_s(t)\$ is modified to \$x_s(t + \alpha(t)) + y(t)\$ by the perturbation, where

a\$\alpha(t)\$ is a changing time shift, or phase deviation, in the periodic output of the unperturbed oscillator;
b\$y(t)\$ is an additive component, which we term the orbital deviation, to the phase-shifted oscillator waveform.

2)

The Preisach model is a phenomenological model which has been primarily known in the area of magnetics [21].

The expression relating the piezoceramic expansion \$f(t)\$ to the excitation voltage \$u(t)\$ is [14], [21]where \$\gamma_{\alpha \beta}[.]\$ are elementary hysteresis operators (elementary relay elements) with switching values \$\alpha\$ and \$\beta\$ and whose values are determined by the input-voltage signal \$u(t)\$ (Fig. 2).
The function \$\mu (\alpha ,\,\beta)\$ is a weighting function estimated from measured data and is called the Preisach function [21].

It is shown later (5) that the weighing function \$\mu (\alpha ,\,\beta )\$ can be directly related to the actuator expansion along the ascending hysteresis curve and first-order reversal curves [21] [Fig. 3(a)].

The application of the classical Preisach model to a piezoceramic stack requires that the wiping-out property (only the current and certain previous input extrema affect the current piezoceramic expansion) and the congruency property are both satisfied [21].

Double differentiation of (5) leads to an expression relating the weighing function \$\mu (\alpha ,\,\beta )\$ to the function \$F(u_{1},\, u_{2})\$ [21]. \$F(u_{1},\, u_{2})\$ can be estimated directly from a database made up of measured piezoceramic expansions along the ascending branch and first-order reversal curves.

This procedure of updating the interface link between the two regions within the limiting triangle is continued as the voltage input signal varies and this leads to a region \$S^{+}\$ in the \$\alpha\$–\$\beta\$ plane that can be used with expression (2)in order to lead to an estimate of the piezoactuator expansion corresponding to any input voltage [21].

In general, the expression for the piezoactuator expansion, in the case of a monotonically increasing input, is [21]where \$f^{CPM}(t)\$ stands for the piezoceramic expansion estimated using the classical Preisach model, \$(n-1)\$ represents the number of maxima/minima stored (not wiped out) and the pairs \$\{(M_{k},\, m_{k})\}\$ represent the sequence of maximum and minimum values of the input signal.
Similarly, if the input \$u(t)\$ is monotonically decreasing, the expression for estimating the piezoceramic expansion is [21].
For points of the \$(M,\, m)\$ plane lying within any of the squares and triangles, bilinear and linear spline interpolation equations are used [21].

Unlike the classical Preisach model that uses the wiping-out property [21]which implies that the current piezoexpansion is influenced only by the series of dominant input extrema (while the input extrema that are followed by more dominant maximum and/or minimum values of the signal are erased from the memory—wiped out), the dynamic-hysteresis model represented by (20) and (21) does not use the wiping-out property as all extrema values are used in the model.

context.text: In Many applications of array processing such as wireless communications, multipath propagation is often encountered due to various reflections, and it causes the direct and reflected signals from a source arriving at an array to be coherent if their delay differences are sufficiently small [2], [5].

Although a linear combination of the array response vectors to the coherent signals (called the “spatial signature (SS)” [8]) is usually not in the array manifold, it is an effective array response to the source and contains sufficient information on the directions of arrival (DOAs) of the signals [5], [6], [8], [13] as the principal eigenvector of array covariance matrix [11].

They include the fourth-order statistics-based forward–backward linear prediction (FBLP) method [5] and extended virtual ESPRIT algorithm [6], the finite-alphabet (FA) property-based method [14], the higher order cyclostationarity-based (HOCS) method [16], and the second-order statistics-based modified Prony (MP) method [7].

Moreover, they suffer serious degradation when the number of snapshots is small, because the fourth-order (cyclic) statistics-based methods [5], [6], [16] require the (cyclic) cumulant to be evaluated; the FA-based method [14]needs an iterative algorithm [15] to solve a nonlinear optimization in SS estimation; and the MP method [7] is sensitive to errors in the estimated SS.

In this letter, we propose a computationally efficient SS-based method for estimating the DOAs of coherent narrowband signals impinging on a uniform linear array (ULA) without any assumption on the temporal structure of incident signals such as the non-Gaussian [5], [6], FA [14], [15], and HOCS [16] properties.

Sabelfeld and Sands [11] connect probabilistic security with probabilistic bisimulation [105] which is a standard semantic model for probabilistic computation.

Ordered linear continuation types enforce a stack discipline that permits a high-precision analysis.
